Award.AwardTitle: Conference Proposal for Strange Quark Matter 2016 at Berkeley, California
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides partial support to offset registration fees for students and post-docs to attend the 16th International Conference on Strangeness in Quark Matter (SQM2016) to be held on June 27-July 1, 2016 at Berkeley, California. The scientific program of the conference will focus on strangeness and heavy quark production in nuclear collisions; Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) phase structure; strangeness in astrophysics; and open questions and new development. Participation of students and post-docs at this meeting will provide them with opportunities for interaction across the scientific community.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of California Berkeley, Clark Kerr Campus

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Strange Quark Matter 2016 conference was held at the Clark Kerr Campus, University of California, Berkeley on June 27 to July 1, 2016. There were over 160 physicists attended the conference. There were 38 plenary talks and 80 parallel session talks. The conference proceedings have been published by IOP publisher and are available as open access at http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1742-6596/779/1/011001. The NSF grant has been used to support post-docs and graduate students to attend the conference. 

The conference covered topics of strangeness and heavy quark production in nuclear collisions and hadronic interactions, QCD phase structure, strangeness in astrophysics, and open questions and new developments in relativisitc heavy ion collisions. 

The SQM2016 conference has taken place while heavy-ion research programs at both RHIC and the LHC continue to generate exciting results. The completion of the Heavy Flavor Tracker (HFT) for STAR and the VTX for PHENIX as well as the campaign for heavy quark physics at RHIC have ushered in an exciting era for heavy quark physics at RHIC. The experiments at the LHC - ALICE, ALTAS, CMS and LHCb – continue to advance the energy frontier. We are very pleased and grateful that many experimental and theoretical results were presented at the conference, mostly by young physicists who represent the future of our growing field.

The conference was organized by Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, University of California Los Angeles and University of California Riverside. The Local Organizing Committee was co-chaired by Dr. Nu Xu (LBNL), Prof. Huan Zhong Huang (UCLA) and Prof. Richard Seto (UCR).


Last Modified: 06/07/2017
Modified by: Huan Z Huang
